course.subject: CENG
course.name: Transport Phenomena I
course.description: Fundamentals of transport phenomena with emphasis on physical properties, flow behavior and diffusive transport of fluids in chemical and biological systems. Engineering derivation and quantitative analysis of fluid transport in confined domains. Emphasis on practical application of transport phenomena in chemical and biological engineering. Use of software for solving problems in transport phenomena.
course.prerequisites: PHYS 1111 OR PHYS 1112 OR PHYS 1312

reviews.author: kimchi
reviews.title: Very difficult but it would be okay if you worked damn hard for it
reviews.comment_content:
1. Viscosity and Newtonian fluids
2. Fluid motion - substantial and material derivative (you need to have a basic idea of kinematics)
3. Manometry, bouyancy - hydrostatics, Pascal's law, surface tension
4. Stream functions
5. Dimension Analysis, friction factor, engineering bernoulli equation (you need some foundation of calculus and solving differential equations and better do some research on fluid mechanics related to human systems because Prof. Hsing is an expert in bioengineering and he likes this topic a lot)
6. Drag on submerged object and packed bed fluidisation
7. Shell momentum balances and velocity distributions (better watch some youtube videos to familiarise yourself with the derivations, his own derivations could be messy sometimes)
8. Microscopic balances and Navier-Stokes Equation, conservation of momentum
9. Application of Navier Stokes Equation, boundary conditions
10. Ordering analysis and boundary layer characteristics (this topic is the hardest in my opinion and I still don't get it)
11. Vorticity and potential flow (the easiest topic)
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a really nice professer and he is willing to stop his teaching for any questions or confusion. He adopts a white-board teaching method in the beginning but since he is quite spontaneous and does not follow the lecture notes when he is explaining, he switched to powerpoint teaching, which I think is better than white-board. But I am not sure if he will do the same for next spring semester.
He assumes all students have strong mathematical skills so be prepared because he commonly skips explanations for certain steps and the pace is a bit fast. He did not highlight the most important things in his notes (his notes are slightly disorganised) so I suggest you to pay 100% attention in class and ask him to provide more help if the lecture material and additional notes are insufficient to understand everything.
reviews.comment_grading:
I expected a lower grade since I am not good at calculus and physics, but turns out I got A- which is very good
Students who are excellent at physics and math should find this course manageable.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 homework in total, almost one per week except the week after study break.
A bit high because the homework are difficult and there are not many youtube videos or online sources that could help. They require you a thorough understanding of the concepts and I did a lot of preparation work before attempting them so each homework took me approx 7-8 hours to do it :(

reviews.author: ahahahahahaha
reviews.title: Transport Phenomena I (Not fluid mechanics) from 2020-21 onwards
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction - Newtonian law of Viscosity and Shear Stress
2. Fluid in Motion (Langrangian and Eulerian)
3. Dimensional Analysis, Frictional Factor, Engineering Bernoulli Equation
4. Fluid Statics: Manometry, Buoyancy
5. Pressure forces
6. Drag on Submerged Objects and Flow of Particulates
7. Shell Momentum Balances and Velocity Distributions
8. Microscopic Balances and Navier-Stokes Equation
9. Application of Navier-Stokes Equation
10. Stream Function, Vortocity and Potential Flow
11. Ordering Analysis and Boundary Layer Characteristics
12. Mass Transport

I don't like the topics - I don't see how they can apply in real life, especially in biological systems (this is a required course for both CENG and BIEN, and the only bio-related example I can find is the arterial pressure thing)
reviews.comment_teaching: I can see that the professor is really trying to teach us every bit about the course. And he really tries to answer your questions and he really listens to our feedback. But no offense to the professor, the teaching is not good. He gave a lot of derivations in class (purely flexing his maths), the writing is hard to read and the materials are not organized. He mainly wrote his examples on whiteboard or annotations on iPad, and they are not matching with our lecture notes (i can't read his lecture notes so I just wrote my own notes for revision). I also think he should give more examples related to either chemical reactions or biological systems. We're always dealing with cylindrical pipes/ flat plates and I have no idea how and when we will use them in real life. Also, he repeats himself so many times in the shell balance lectures, which is really unnecessary (maybe he thinks we're dumb). In one of the lectures he just explained why force is negative and I think that's really redundant. If you want to understand clearly on the lecture materials, just go to youtube fluid mechanics tutorials for help. I think the professor is quite nice though so you can always ask him for help. I think the TAs are quite helpful and they're really quick in replying emails and marking assignments/exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 25% (8 in total)
Midterm 35%
Final 40%

All homework together: 92.5/100 (Mean ~ 70.33, unknown sd)
Midterm: 69/100 (Mean: 46.86, SD: ~ 18, High: 84)
Final: 97/115 (Mean: 54.71, unknown sd, High: 99)

I only expected an A cuz my midterm was quite low (?) compared to the highest score. I knew the midterm high and the final high weren't the same person so I expect those two to get A+. I ended up with an A+ that's really a surprise. Not sure how the professor distributed the grades (Maybe >2 A+s in a 71 ppl class?). That's classic CENG grading - you work hard and you'll get satisfactory grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 8 homework (yes, 8, even more than thermodynamics). Some questions appear to be really weird since he never mentioned it (first homework has torque, and I search it up from some fluid mechanics tutorial on youtube). Half of them are easy ones (<1 hour to complete), the others should take some time but still no more than 3 hours. Other than that we only have two exams.
Midterm has one question about surface tension which I found quite ridiculous cuz he didn't even spend 5 mins during his lecture - it is 16 marks btw, out of 100. You should really revise for every piece of material he gave cuz you never know when they would appear. The exams are of classic CENG difficulty with super low mean so no worries.
For the tutorial/recitations, the TAs are there to explain homework and exams and anything that you might have questions on. As long as you understand the hw and exam questions, you don't have to go (I didn't attend any except the first two).
There are extra tutorials offered by UG TAs which are not too relevant to the course materials (some of the examples are aerodynamics) but it's a good source for you to learn more if you want. They're optional.

reviews.author: Zeddest
reviews.title: Quite Difficult Course but with Decent Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Properties of Fluids
Pressure and Statics of Fluids
Fluid Kinematics and RTT
Mass Bernoulli Energy Equations
Momentum Analysis of Flow Systems
Dimensional Analysis and Modeling
Experimental Testing and Similarity
Internal Flows
Differential Analysis

In contrast to the easy midterm, the difficulty of the final exam is escalated. However, the questions are very different from the one in homework and lectures.

The class schedule is quite fast but the professor will repeat the materials taught previously in each lesson. As mentioned by the professor, fluid dynamics is a very board course, it is encouraged to read the textbook if you want to get a good score in the final. Despite the heavy calculated-based midterm, the final test a lot on the kinematics concept.

Only handwritten notes are allowed for the midterm and final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very nice. He will give some demonstration on the abstract concept and willing to answer students' questions. However, the learning environment is not that engaging since he expects silence from students meaning they understand the content.

Please go to the tutorial! They provide a lot of help and teach examples similar to the homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for Spring 2019 is
Homework 20%
Midterm 20%
Final 60%

Unlike previous years, the grading depends heavily on the final, but most students did not perform well in the final as the questions ask a lot about concepts with less calculation. The mean for the final is around 50 out of 100 in contrast with the high mean in the midterm.

I got almost full marks in the midterm and homework, but mean for the final. My grade is A- so overall is not that bad.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is relatively light with 6 homework throughout the course. They are like the advanced version of the examples in tutorials so you better attend all of it, but it is still difficult. For the midterm and final, they will provide a review session and past papers to help clarify the concepts. Personally, it's not that helpful as the question styles are vastly different.

reviews.author: arthurwang
reviews.comment_content:

Normally in the US, fluid mechanics will be put in year 3. But somehow HKUST students need to take it in year 2. The content requires a lot of background knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof tried very hard to arouse students' interest, but the content was too hard and boring. He would try to remember each face, and he remembered that I stopped going to classes after midterm lol.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad to be honest. I got mean for midterm, and I didn't know how much I got for final (grades weren't released). And I got A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost one assignment every week, and you need to submit only in hand-written format.

reviews.author: Apple5682

reviews.author: LIFEGOOD
reviews.title: VERY HEAVY Math and Physics course
reviews.comment_content:
Basically the same as the previous courses

1. Introduction - Newtonian law of Viscosity and Shear Stress
2. Fluid in Motion (Langrangian and Eulerian)
3. Dimensional Analysis, Frictional Factor, Engineering Bernoulli Equation
4. Fluid Statics: Manometry, Buoyancy
5. Pressure forces
6. Drag on Submerged Objects and Flow of Particulates
7. Shell Momentum Balances and Velocity Distributions
8. Microscopic Balances and Navier-Stokes Equation
9. Application of Navier-Stokes Equation
10. Stream Function, Vortocity and Potential Flow
11. Ordering Analysis and Boundary Layer Characteristics
12. Mass Transport

Although Mass Transport was covered at the end of the semester, it did not appear in the final exam.

Overall, this course is basically a Math class, with ALOT of Calculus, and vectors (including del operator, Taylor series, second derivatives, double integrations and etc).

Personally, it took me very long time to understand the lecture contents as I am not very good at Calculus and physics. Having said that, if you are good at math or physics and spend a lot of time  for this course, you will be fine I guess.

Also, it is not required to understand how to derive equations before the Mid-term. In the exam, you just need to know how to apply the equations into different situations. But, for finals, you are required to know how to derive them. The final exam requires you to derive the equation by yourselves starting from the fundamental equations. Personally, second-half of the materials are easier to understand if you watch lectures carefully.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor I-Ming is a passionate professor, who replies my email immediately. Before the Mid-terms, I really really found it hard to understand this teaching as lecture contents are very very hard. He expects you to be familiarized with vector operations in 3D dimensions. There are not many YouTube videos that explain the similar concepts. So I ended up re-watching lecture videos multiple times. However, for the second-half of the material, he teach better and it was much better to understand. The equations get much harder but a lot of terms get cancelled, so it slightly made my life better.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 20%
Mid-term 35%
Final exam 45%

Class mean grade
HW : ~75%
Midterm: 51.7 / 100
Final Exam : 50.7/115

My grade
HW : 85%
Midterm: 50/100
Final Exam : 64/115

Letter Grade : B+

Overall, I was slightly above mean, and I got B+  letter grade. I guess the mean is around B/B+
I am very very satisfied with my result, as I could not understand many of  the lecture contents, but I still ended up with higher than mean. I guess many classmates also did not understand the lecture material.

HWs are marked by 50% on accuracy, and 50% on effort. This means that even if you did wrong, you can still get a lot of points if you used the correct equations and made the right approach. But having the right approach was also hard lol.
Good luck. You will definitely have tough times.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 7 HWs
Basically one HW per week. Around 4 Questions per HW. No similar questions could be found online, and I personally found them very very hard. It requires you to understand lecture materials thoroughly, and apply them in the questions. When you first read the questions, you will be surprised by how difficult they are. Most are very very lengthy and you may not even understand what the questions are finding. It took me at least 4 hours to complete each HW. It was really a bad experience, and I am very glad that I completed them now. I took this course alongside with CENG 2210 (which is also considered hard course), but CENG 2220 made Thermodynamics course (CENG 2210) relatively easy.

reviews.author: pdawg
reviews.title: Confusing Course On a Confusing Subject
reviews.comment_content:
Properties of Fluids
Pressure and Statics of Fluids
Fluid Kinematics
Mass Bernoulli Energy Equations
Momentum Analysis of Flow Systems
Dimensional Analysis and Modeling
Flow in Pipes

A very calculation-based class. The midterm is very simple, which is in stark contrast to a very difficult final.

The schedule also covers things quite fast, so expect to use the textbook to supplement any gaps in knowledge. Then again, fluids is a very broad course in any university, and in other countries it can be a 2 semester class. If you want to truly understand this course, it is encouraged to read on your own.

It's also very hard to retain any information from this class because only some of it carries on to Ping Gao's heat and mass transfer. This might be my own bias though because I don't have the best memory (or GPA for that matter).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ciucci is a nice guy, but he is not the most engaging of lecturers. Another thing is that he will assume that silence from the class while he teaches means that everyone comprehends what is going on, when it's not hard to guess that the opposite is happening.

He will use the whiteboard to do some calculations and algebraic manipulation, so don't rely on the powerpoint alone because its educational value is rather scarce.
reviews.comment_grading:
I took this class in Spring 2018. Prior to this class the grading was much more strict.

Homework 25%
Midterm 25%
Final 50%

I was more than 1 s.d. above the mean for the midterms, but the final's difficulty was greatly increased relative to midterms. However the final score was not released, and I got an A, which was a very very unexpected result. I might have just been fortunate, but from asking my cohort it appears the mean has been shifted to almost B or B+. Either way, don't count on this to happen every year.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework is quite difficult. But relatively light workload. It comes down to how seriously you'd take this class, because you have to be self driven to learn the material, and if you're a less than capable student, like myself, that can take a LOT of note writing. Good luck.
